thread.title: The eight best road-trip films of all time
thread.title_full: The eight best road-trip films of all time - Telegraph

author: Paul Connolly
title: The eight best road-trip films of all time
text: >> More extraordinary road tales With the open road ahead and the sense of adventure taking over – there’s a reason why everyone loves a good road trip. But where will you go next? We all need inspiration to fuel our imaginations, so use these eight classic road-trip movies to spark your next two-lane odyssey. From whimsical pootling around the Lake District to hurtling through the deserts of the US, these movies provide ideas for all sorts of car journeys. Thelma & Louise (1991) Girl power: Susan Sarandon and Geena Davis on the drive of their lives Photo: Rex Shutterstock Thelma (Geena Davis) joins her friend Louise (Susan Sarandon) for a short fishing trip. After an unfortunate incident at a bar, the friends set off on a wild tour of the Wild West, along the way picking up Brad Pitt and hundreds of policemen. Trivia: George Clooney auditioned for the role of the feckless JD, ultimately played by Pitt. Planes, Trains and Automobiles (1987) Opposites attract: Unlikely travel companions Steve Martin and John Candy Photo: Alamy Steve Martin plays Neal, a rich, high-maintenance ad man trying to get back home for the Thanksgiving holidays. His companion? John Candy stars as Del, a travelling salesman from Chicago who sells shower curtain rings ("the best in the world”). The result? An opposites-don’t-attract comedy classic. Trivia: The exterior of the aircraft in flight is a reuse of the plane flying through the storm from the 1980 film Airplane ! Duel (1971) Road rage: Steven Spielberg's terror in the Californian desert Photo: Rex Shutterstock Never mind the shark in Jaws , the huge truck in Steven Spielberg’s first movie was a terrifyingly aggressive beast as it chased poor Dennis Weaver through the Californian desert. Taut, mean and still shockingly good. Trivia: Duel was a TV movie, and only received a limited theatrical release in the US. Little Miss Sunshine (2006) Little ray of sunshine: a star is born in a bright yellow VW camper Photo: Rex Shutterstock When Olive (Abigail Breslin) learns she has qualified for the Little Miss Sunshine beauty contest that ' s being held in California in two days, she's ecstatic. However, the only way to make the 800-mile trip from New Mexico is if the entire household goes – in a VW Camper. Trivia: Bryan Cranston and Dean Norris, both to achieve stardom in Breaking Bad , have small parts in Little Miss Sunshine . Road To Morocco (1942) Camels and carriages: Road trip, Moroccan-style Photo: Alamy The best of the Road To… movies features carpetbagging wisecrackers Bob Hope and Bing Crosby, who are shipwrecked on the African coast. Commandeering a stubborn camel (who wisecracks back), they set off on the road to Morocco to woo the lovely Dorothy Lamour. Trivia: The film became topical when, two days before its premiere, US troops landed in Morocco as part of the Second World War’s Operation Torch. Sideways (2004) Wine country: Toasting to a mid-life crisis Photo: Alamy In this deliciously bittersweet movie, Jack and Miles (Thomas Haden Church and Paul Giamatti) both approaching a hugely unsatisfactory middle age, embark on a week-long road trip through California's wine country. Trivia: During his audition, Thomas Haden Church stripped naked because that was what the scene called for. He later learned that he was the only actor to do that. The Trip (2010) What a trip: Coogan and Brydon were a surprise hit Photo: Rex Shutterstock Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon’s hilarious and visually stunning restaurant-reviewing road trip through the Lake District became a surprise minor hit in the US after its theatrical release in 2011. Trivia: There is no credited writer. The majority of the dialogue in the film was improvised by Coogan and Brydon. The Straight Story (1999) The straight and narrow: One man and his lawnmower Photo: Alamy David Lynch’s unusually disciplined retelling of the true story of Alvin Straight (Richard Farnsworth) who rides his 1961 lawnmower from Laurens, Iowa, to Mt. Zion, Wisconsin, to visit his ill, estranged brother, is simple, funny and moving. Trivia: Richard Farnsworth had just had hip surgery in real life, so a special seat for the tractor was made for him. • Whether you're taking a road trip or just commuting to work, it's best to be prepared.
